Will you do an anagram in the wrong section? (this one)

i used to do them here, before there was an anagrams page. i used to respond to any question asking about anagrams by anagramming the question instead of answering it. this unfortunately lead down a rabbit hole of people asking for longer and longer anagrams. this was thrilling for me, but the really long ones were actually taking me all day. and with the format of this page, i can't save them for later, because i always answer questions in chronological order. so basically it would stall the questions page (or else i would have to skip it, which i didn't want to do). this is really what made me realize i need to build the anagrams page, and take requests, and i can take them out of order and just work on them whenever i get a chance

So is your last note written in 2016 and you are updating the notebook page with previously written notes?

well, it really depends what counts. which has been an ongoing blurred line for quite some time. particularly after i started writing for twitter regularly in 2014. nowadays each update for "new" content to the notebook page actually consists of mostly combing through all my tweets and picking out which ones seem to be more central to me, and weeding out the ones that seem to just be composed to fill space on twitter. then uploading them and tracking down the dates, preferably when it was written, not when it was tweeted (there is often a several day difference.) and ALSO a new notes update entails going through my files and finding other things that i have written which might work well exclusively for the notes page. but there are less and less of those, over time, because while i used to use text as both an outlet for journaling and creativity, nowadays my primary outlet for journaling is audio recordings, and my primary outlet for creativity is audio/visual content. so what's happening is, in terms of newly written content for the notebook page, the vast majority of it will be things that have already been released on twitter. so in other words, when i do the next big "new" notebook update, it's going to be 95% tweets that you would have already seen if you follow my twitter page. and if you follow my twitter page you will see a new tweet every day. in addition i am constantly filling in more and more content from the past (much longer stuff, not tweets). people constantly ask my "why i don't use the notebook page anymore" but i continue to use it for the same purpose i have always used it, and furthermore if you want to see the new content, it's on twitter, every day. i hope that makes sense

What's it called when you divide the beats into 6 equally spaced hits, like if the time signature is still 4/4 but instead of playing 16th notes you play 6 (instead of 4) for each beat? I'm guessing they're not called 24th notes lol. How would you write that out?

well, computer programs actually sometimes do call it 24th notes, just because it's consistent, mathematically. But, ... in writing it is usually called some type of triplet or sextuplet. in your situation, i would prefer to call it "16th note triplets" for clarity's sake, although i'm sure people would just say 'sextuplets' and assume you know what they mean. i prefer to write it as a group of 6 notes, double beam, except only a single beam between the 3rd and 4th notes. so 2 groups of 3 16th notes, connected in the middle by a single beam. you can put the triplet arc (and number 3) over each group of 3. or if you want i guess you could put one arc over the whole thing and put 6. that works too, i guess. i hope that answers your question

So my parents aren't musicians but my mom tells me she used to obsessively play classical music a bunch while she was pregnant with me. I didn't touch a keyboard until I was 6 or 7. Anyway, now I'm 20 and I've been doing music stuff for like 10+ years with few lessons(or direction) but I know middle "C" indefinitely. And because I know "C" i can figure out every other note too(maybe I'm not explaining this right) my point is i can figure out any notes to a thing as long as I think from "C" first. I explained this to my teacher and he was like "that's perfect pitch" but I always thought perfect pitch was effortless.
right. you have a very effective and wily workaround, which i have as well
Honestly it doesn't matter much to me cuz I got to where I was thinking I'm relative pitch so even if I don't have perfect pitch It's not like it's impossible to be good with relative.

right. to be a musician, relative pitch is 100% required. perfect pitch (otherwise known as "absolute pitch") really doesn't have anything to do with music and is not required at all to be a good musician, and is really not even a reliable indicator of good musicianship
I was just wondering I you ever heard of this kind of thing. Take care. -bro-bro

but here's the ironic thing: there are many many people who frolic all over the place telling people they have perfect pitch, but whenever you test them, they're not even close. my point is, if you have the skill that you have (springboarding off a strong memory of C) then not only can you get the job done, but you can probably do it better than most people who actually claim to have it. so i say you might as well just say you have it. to increase your strength, familiarize yourself with where a low C is in your vocal register, (you can usually hum it quietly, should be a casual and easy note for a male, if you are a male) and just practice trying to find that note while other songs are playing. also familiarize yourself with the key of every song you've ever heard, and always learn what key songs are in. this will help you even more. perfect pitch (absolute pitch), or the sneaky workaround you have, is not at all required to be a wonderful and great musician, BUT it will provide you with an extra edge in professional situations

I never understood the circle of fifths 
Also why is it fifths and fiths?

i think if you look at keys, like the key of C, ..... then look at the key of G. you'll notice that the key of G uses exactly the same notes as the key of C but you only have to change one note. then if you look at the key of D (which is in the same relation from G as G was from C) you'll notice again that D contains almost exactly the same notes as G, but you just have to change one note. and so on. the next key in the same pattern would be A. again, you only have to change one note from the key of D to get the key of A. each time you're adding a sharp, and it's always in the same position relative to the new key (it's always the 7th degree). perhaps the circle of fifths seems a little more useful now. it goes the other way too, except instead of adding a sharp you are taking away a sharp, or if there's none left then a flat gets added

(ref: q.php?date=201710161257)10.16.1712:57 pm  I think you said that you mostly use a voice memo thing for getting ideas down when they come to you... do you usually just sing the main melody? Are you able to come up with chords/harmony in your head, and if so, how would you record that? What about drum parts/bass line?

melody, lyric, then just explain anything else that seems important or not obvious. chords for a melody are often obvious. like when you draw a duck's head, it's pretty much assumed that you're gonna have a duck's body there too. another important thing is to count it off, because a melody sung out of thin air can be ambiguous about where the top of the bar is. so i might count off, might orient the key in case it's not clear, might clarify what the chords are if necessary, and for the groove i might quickly sing something or might compare it to another song's groove, for reference. if i have a keyboard available i might play/sing a quick demo. i often over explain, especially in terms of count-off, because new ideas can disappear easily and you might not know how the time is oriented so i try to be as clear as possible

Question for Bill Wurtz on (ref: q.php?date=201710011623)10.1.17 4:23 pm : "define random."

Bill says chosen without reason blah blah preferably by computer to eliminate accidental reasoning

I feel the particular response to be inadequate due to some research

"One thing that traditional computer systems aren't good at is coin flipping," says Steve Ward, Professor of Computer Science and Engineering at MIT's Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory. "They're deterministic, which means that if you ask the same question you'll get the same answer every time. In fact, such machines are specifically and carefully programmed to eliminate randomness in results. They do this by following rules and relying on algorithms when they compute."

You can program a machine to generate what can be called "random" numbers, but the machine is always at the mercy of its programming. "On a completely det erminist ic machine you can't generate anything you could really call a random sequence of numbers," says Ward, "because the machine is following the same algorithm to generate them. Typically, that means it starts with a common 'seed' number and then follows a pattern." The results may be sufficiently complex to make the pattern difficult to identify, but because it is ruled by a carefully defined and consistently repeated algorithm, the numbers it produces are not truly random. "They are what we call 'pseudo-random' numbers," Ward says.

- MIT School of Engineering

How do you feel about this? Will you stay with your stance of preferring computers to eliminate accidental reasoning or have you been influenced to believe that the machine can never trump human creativity

it's a known fact, and proven countless time that isolation and lack of human contact is the worst pain a human can suffer,
yeah i know it's pretty bad
but in your case it seems that not creating is the worst pain you can suffer,
that's true too
and that you'd rather be alone and create than the opposite, how come ?

well i'm not necessarily alone by choice. i've probably talked about this before, but that's an ongoing question. throughout school i was always very aware that i wanted so badly to be 'included' and have a great group of friends and have lots of fun, but that consistently never became a reality, year after year, for reasons i could never figure out. but there was another thing happening too, which was that i sort of had an infinite world of musical and artistic vision going on, which no one else seemed to relate to. it seems there were infinite things i wanted to figure out and create. and i was always extremely disappointed that no one seemed capable or willing to go on this journey with me. and i think every time i tried to fit in, the reality is that i probably couldn't hide the fact that i was bored with everyone. i was trying not to be, because i wanted so bad to fit in and have friends, but i think in most cases people thought that it was ME who was not interested in THEM. anyway, this pattern continued on and on, through school and beyond. and i continued to develop my skills and ideas fiercely and passionately, sort of regretting being alone but making the most of it, and also clinging on to various threads of social contact .... until one day in a particularly bad season socially (like really there was no one to hang out with), i hit a turning point and realized that i've always known i could and should accomplish something really really serious with my life, and i should probably just accept the fact that i'm going to do this alone. and that's when i really really got serious and professional about it, and keeping journals, and really just working toward it even more seriously than before. that was years ago, and since then i have really no longer had that 'panicked' feeling of being alone -- i accepted it as part of the picture, and never looked back. and i've gotten an insane amount of work done and launched my career. and it's been so many years now that i am totally comfortable and used to the alone-ness, but occasionally maybe a couple times a year it just gets really really annoying

seems a bit like you underestimate instrumental music?

no, trust me, i am Hard-Wired as an instrumental musician. in my childhood i listened to only instrumental music, and didn't know how to really deal with anything else. the first many years of my musical development were vastly instrumental only. mostly artists who's music was marketed as instrumental music, in its own right. but there is an elephant in the room, which everyone always thinks about, which is "why do those instrumental artists never seem to be as successful as non-instrumental artists, even though *we* (musicians) 'know' they're 'better' " etc etc sad face. i just didn't feel like going along with such a sad conclusion so i was driven to understand, so i erased everything i knew and started listening to pop radio all day. anyway, that's beside the point, what i'm trying to say is, over time it became crystal clear that instrumental music operates in the back part of your brain, but the labels, the handles, the latches, the characters, the *cognition* as the scientists would call it, happens in the 'front' part of your brain. i guess it's called the frontal lobe, or the neo-cortex, or whatever .. (not a brain expert really) but it's kind of like where you file things. it's what you name things. even if the *feelings* and the deep stuff are all happening on a much deeper level, you will always have them 'filed' or 'named' in a particular way. and each person may file things differently. but that's what i realized about instrumental music. vastly powerful, usually doing most of the real heavy lifting in terms of actually making the over-all product feel good, does all work in terms of pulling the heartstrings, BUT the frontal 'handles' (characters, words, names, titles, etc etc, the frontal stuff) will always seem to get the credit. that's just the way it works. and the same is true for my childhood listening to instrumental music -- for example, let's say an album of instrumental music is sold under a particular musician's name, and they play a certain instrument (let's say it's piano). that's the 'frontal' content, the label / title etc... in other words, when you listen to it, you are 'cognizant' of the fact that you are listening to a piano player's music. you are aware that that is what's happening. so if that reality is something you are comfortable with, then you will be comfortable listening to that music. where-as, take for example, a movie, with scenes in it about troubles in a relationship due to long distance separation, etc etc etc, but it happens to be underscored by piano. you are still listening to instrumental piano music, but you whole idea of what's happening will be different. you will probably think of it as 'i'm watching this scene in a movie about these characters etc this is what's going on" rather than "i'm listening to piano music" ... now not everyone necessarily files things the same way, because for example someone interested in film scoring could easily be listening to it and hearing the underscoring, and that's likely a main reason they would be watching the movie, to specifically enjoy the underscoring. but even so, that reality is still different from listening to a piano player's album, because the film-scoring person is not just listening to the score, but they are listening to it from a film-scorers perspective. when we are studying and learning things, that often determines the angle we focus on. another example, let's say it comes from a video game. the music will have all it's power but it will be connected with the game, and the game will again act as the 'handle' or 'filing system' that sort of 'delivers' the music to the listener, and in turn the music is richly juicing up the contents of the game, to feel so much more meaning, and again usually the 'handles' (the content of the game) will get all the credit. unless, again, it is a music student or a musician listening, in which case That would be their 'handle.' so even when instrumental music seems to be purely insrumental with nothing else, there is always some context in which the listener heard it. for example, let's say you are walking down the street and all of a sudden you randomly hear instrumental music coming out of a fire-hydrant. well guess what, that's not just detached music, that's music you heard coming out of that fire hydrant, and when you tell the story you will always remember that music as the music that was coming out of that fire hydrant. so in that sense the only way to actually have completely unfiled unassociated instrumental music is if you were hearing the music and you literally don't know where it's coming from and you also don't know where you are, and also don't remember the circumstances that led to you not knowing where you are. so basically my point is that yes truly and surely instrumental music has all the powers. but it is made of liquid and you really can't drink any of it unless you have a cup

Hi Bill! Sorry if you're tired of getting hotewig questions.. but I'd like to know more about your thought process/goals for writing the intro part. After the big bang, there's pretty much a straightforward story line for you to follow (if you can call the history of the world straightforward)... but everything from "hi, you're on a rock..." up until "i think there's a universe now" must've been really tricky to write. The origin of the universe (and history of the universe) seems like a real tough story to set the scene for. Did you find it hard to come up with a good intro for the video? (Btw I think you nailed it).

that was probably the most fun part. explaining the motivations for a universe happening, from the perspective of there not being a universe. and it's really common sense, i think, if you look at it from the right perspective, but the problem is you are not allowed to properly use time or space in the description because those things only exist if there is a universe. and most language as we know it is based on time and space. so it makes for some thrilling turns of phrase
